description: Russell James' comment has been very useful. Does anyone know how to make subtitles available? Subtitles are meant to be downloaded also, but they are not available when playing the video back.

I used this app for a while then it quit working. Apparently the one from apt is outdated because it was coming up with a warning and the version was sowing in 2018. This one works and show the version in 2019. For the people that are saying the app opens then closes right back down, that is because this is a command line app. You have to open terminal then type in youtube-dl then the web address then any options. Clicking on the app most likely opens terminal then closes because there are no parameters. To learn more check YouTube for tutorials or in terminal type man youtube-dl. This app does work and it works good, but if you are not used to command line it may be harder than you want to do. This is actually faster and you have more control over what it does.

Try Youtubedl Official GUI app here:-

This a a commandline app (program). No GUI. Easy to use.:
youtube-dl ' url copied from address bar or share link' 
Thats the most basic use. If you get an error use: youtube-dl -U   This updates youtube-dl. Youtube.com changes there scripts/servers whatever sometimes, so its important to keep youtube-dl up to date.
Typing youtube-dl --help in the terminal will show how many options there are with this program. Its quite easy to use in a script or downloading muliple videos, or stripping the audio and saving in many supported audio/ video formats. As the previous comment said a quick search on internet will give many examples. I hope this helps.

That's how i install it, then run it from a command line as normal... 

sudo wget https://yt-dl.org/latest/youtube-dl -O /usr/local/bin/youtube-dl
sudo chmod a+x /usr/local/bin/youtube-dl
hash -r

Enjoy it!!

This is an amazing command line program that is extremely useful and versatile for downloading video and audio from the internet.  By learning a few of the code letters one can view video and audio files available on a webpage and then select the desired files for download.  Separate audio and video formats can be selected and downloaded - the 2 files are then merged together automatically  into one Mp4 file.  Subtitles can be downloaded separately from a video and saved as a text file.  One time I downloaded Chinese subtitles from a video and ran them through Google Translate.  The program needs to be updated every month or so to keep up with youtube security measures.  It is a simple thing to update.

The terminal codes I often use are:

To list available formats:
youtube-dl -F https://www.youtube.com/watch?v= example

To download desired formats and merge them into an Mp4:
youtube-dl -f 137+140 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v= example

To download subtitles and save them as a text file to home folder:
youtube-dl --write-auto-sub https://www.youtube.com/watch?v= example

It's also possible to download an entire list of movies. 
Open a simple text program and copy / paste a list of youtube video URLs you want to watch (one video URL per line). Save the text document as: list

Then in terminal type this code:

cd ~/Desktop
youtube-dl -a list

The youtube-dl program will then start downloading the best version of each video on the list one at a time and save it to your desktop.

Youtube-dl can do a lot more too. Oh one last thing: If you open terminal you can just press up arrow on the keyboard to go through previous instructions. Usually you get to an instruction you need so you don't have to type it all out again.
